newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk banks '96 deposits up at 6,024 trln lira.
newsitem.headline: Turk banks '96 deposits up at 6,024 trln lira.

text.p: Turkish banks' total lira and foreign currency deposits rose 28 percent in real terms to 6,024 trillion lira in 1996, from 2,665 trillion lira in 1995, a treasury report said.

It said Turkish lira deposits totalled 3,028 trillion lira in 1996, and their share in the total rose to 50 percent from 45 percent in 1995 due to higher real returns on the lira and lira depreciation against major currencies lagging behind inflation.

The report said investors shifted their savings to short-term repurchase agreements (repos) from deposits to benefit from higher t-bill and bond yields, producing difficulties in the effectiveness of the monetary policy.

"Although a maturity gap between banks and private investors' bond protfolios raised a potential liquidity risk, the system has the power and mechanisms to localise and solve this problem," the report said.
It added that positive developments in the banks' liquidity ratios was a sign of it.

Banks' total repo trading volume stood at 1,136 trillion lira in 1996 and the overall ratio of repo volume to total deposits was 18.9 in the banking system. This ratio was 10.7 in state banks, 25.5 in private banks and 13.4 in foreign banks.
The report said overdue repayments on extended loans of the Turkish banks rose to 29.88 trillion lira in 1996 from 20.88 trillion a year ago.
But it added that the share of overdue loan repayments in total loans dropped continuously in the recent years.
